message.content: We refer to the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest rotator cuff injury. MRI is the best test to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of injury. Physical exam and history alone may suggest the diagnosis but cannot confirm it definitively. Radiography and ultrasound are not as sensitive to detecting rotator cuff injuries as MRI.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest rotator cuff tear, but MRI is needed to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the tear. Physical exam and history alone cannot confirm the diagnosis, and radiography and ultrasound may not provide enough detail.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While physical exam and history are important in diagnosing shoulder injuries, an MRI would provide the most detailed view of the underlying pathology, such as a rotator cuff tear or impingement syndrome. Radiography and ultrasound may not be as sensitive for detecting soft tissue injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While physical exam and history can give us evidential clues for the diagnosis, MRI will provide a more conclusive diagnosis. In this case, the patient's history of weight lifting and martial arts suggests rotator cuff injury, but MRI will confirm the extent of damage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Physical exam and history suggest rotator cuff injury, which can be confirmed with an MRI. Radiography and ultrasound may not show the injury clearly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a rotator cuff tear, but physical exam and history alone cannot confirm the underlying diagnosis. MRI is the best imaging modality for diagnosing rotator cuff tears. Radiography and ultrasound may be used as adjuncts, but they are not the best options for confirming the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While physical exam and history are important, an MRI can confirm the underlying diagnosis and provide more detailed information about the injury. Radiography and ultrasound may not provide sufficient information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with shoulder pain and weakness, which suggests rotator cuff injury. While physical exam and history can suggest the diagnosis, MRI is the best option for confirmation as it can show the extent of the injury and guide treatment. Radiography and ultrasound may be helpful in ruling out other possible causes of the shoulder pain, but they are less useful in confirming rotator cuff injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While physical exam and history may suggest a rotator cuff injury, an MRI is the most confirmatory test to assess for injury, location, and severity. Radiography and ultrasound may also show some findings but are less sensitive and specific compared to an MRI.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While physical exam and history are important in diagnosing shoulder injuries, an MRI is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing rotator cuff tears, which is the likely underlying diagnosis in this case. Radiography may be used to rule out other conditions, such as fractures or dislocations, but would not confirm a rotator cuff tear. Ultrasound can also be used to diagnose rotator cuff tears but is less sensitive than MRI.
